The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. Our approach is based on the observation that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear functions between the categories of probability spaces and Borel measures. This result is a generalization of the celebrated Gelfand–Naimark theorem, which is a special case of our result. Our approach provides a framework for the reconstruction of quantum theory from a categorical point of view.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a variety of hosts. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we report the results of a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. The disease is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), which is able to evade the host immune response by blocking IFN-mediated antiviral signaling. The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels.

Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a global dataset of maize production and climate variability to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is important for understanding the mechanisms of coexistence in natural assemblages. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the complex mixtures of plant material consumed. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and digestive physiology, species differed in their proportional grass consumption, suggesting that species may partition food resources in ways that are not easily predicted from their trophic guild. Our results suggest that the extent of food-resource partitioning may be greater than previously thought, and that the diversity of large mammalian herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a large-scale survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. However, the length of the crisis is uncertain, and many businesses expect to remain open for some time. Many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many small businesses expect to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude and the fate of this pollution are still open questions. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system formed from the material of the protosolar nebula, which condensed out of the early solar system. The solar system is thought to have formed from the material of a protosolar nebula that was enriched by the ejecta of stars that formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort (CPUE) has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase reproductive output is a defining characteristic of all animals. In this study, we show that the ability to increase reproductive output is also a defining characteristic of all mammals. We show that the ability to increase reproductive output is correlated with the amount of energy available to the mother. This energy is provided by the mother’s own body, or by the body of another individual. We show that the amount of energy available to the mother is a strong limiting factor on reproductive output, and that this limiting factor is not resource availability, but rather the mother’s own metabolic power.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. Furthermore, our results suggest that caspase-1 could be a potential target for the development of new therapeutic strategies for MSA and other synucleinopathies. The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the human body. It is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system, including the control of blood pressure, the regulation of inflammation, and the control of the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources, and to coordinate its responses. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that are connected by short paths, and that this network is highly efficient in the transmission of information. The network is therefore effective in both local and global communication, and is able to rapidly and robustly respond to changes in the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In response, we have developed the COVIDcast API, an open-source platform that provides a common interface to a wide range of COVID-19 data. The API provides access to both traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in potassium channels. The activation gate closes before the selectivity filter opens, and this allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We also show that this residue is essential for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter in the closed state. This work provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the absence of the activation gate. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the absence of the activation gate.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential for the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could be used as a source of therapeutics. We find that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize a diverse array of natural products, and that these fungi are likely to be a source of novel compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, is reflected in the mitochondrial function of the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness of high-anxious individuals is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens and that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with desired behaviors is a critical issue in the development of mechanical systems. In this work, we propose a synthesis strategy to design structures that can realize any prescribed mechanical response under large deformation. The proposed approach is based on a digital representation of the structure, which is synthesized to be optimal in terms of the target behaviors. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and exhibit irregular material distributions and complex shapes. The responses of the structures are experimentally validated, and the structures are further assembled into architectures to demonstrate the programmability of the devices. The proposed synthesis, fabrication, and assembly strategy can be utilized to design mechanical devices with specific behaviors for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major regulator of the timing of development in mammals. In this study, we demonstrate that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. We show that IGF2BP1 is down-regulated in fetal versus adult bone marrow and that its overexpression in erythroid cells results in a reversal of the adult pattern of hemoglobin expression toward a more fetal-like pattern. This is achieved by increased gamma-globin combined with decreased beta-globin transcripts resulting in gamma-globin rising to 90% of total beta-like mRNA. Delta-globin mRNA is reduced to barely detectable levels. This study provides a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis, highly prevalent in cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance, and that this resistance is mediated by the transcription factor sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1) and the fatty acid desaturase SCD1. We also found that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis, and that this combination therapy is effective in preclinical models of cancer. Our findings provide a rationale for the development of new therapies for cancer. (Read more)

Hypertension is the most common risk factor for heart failure, and the treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs), which are effective in lowering blood pressure. However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells, which is mediated by the N terminus of STIM proteins. Our findings may help to explain the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of hypertension. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest land in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted clearcutting on federal land, but that the policy has not yet reversed the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings suggest that the NWFP needs to be complemented by other conservation efforts to ensure the long-term persistence of these species.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. In this work, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work provides a proof of concept for the use of computational approaches in the design of new antibiotics. The results of this work are expected to be of interest to the scientific community and to the pharmaceutical industry. The compounds designed by us are available for licensing.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is one of the most diverse and iconic groups of vertebrates on Earth. The lake is also one of the most dynamic freshwater ecosystems, with dramatic changes in lake level over the past 1.3 My. We show that the lake level changes are consistent with a shift in the position of the Intertropical Convergence Zone, which is a key climate system that influences the distribution of moisture in the tropics. The shift in the ITCZ position is consistent with a change in the strength of the Walker Circulation, which is a key climate system that influences the distribution of moisture in the tropics.
The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is increasing rapidly. This study shows that this practice has a negative impact on sleep, with consequences for health and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is thought to have been triggered by one or more bolide impacts. The impact hypothesis is supported by varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules at the YDB. In support of the impact hypothesis, we show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the magnetic grains and microspherules is consistent with terrestrial origin. However, the Os concentration in the magnetic grains and microspherules is much lower than that in average upper continental crust, indicating that the impact hypothesis is not supported by the data. The Os isotopic composition of the spherules from the YDB site in Pennsylvania is consistent with the impact hypothesis, but the Os concentration is much lower than that in the impact melt.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the adult is largely unknown. Here, we report that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in the adult, and that its expression in the thymus and in T cells is required for the development of autoimmunity. We also show that CTLA-4 deficiency in the adult has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4 deficiency in the adult protects against collagen-induced arthritis, it promotes the development of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. These findings have important implications for the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system and in the development of autoimmunity.

The order Coleoptera is arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We reconstructed the evolutionary history of beetles using a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes, and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of these genes in the fossil record. These findings suggest that these novel genes enabled efficient digestion of plant tissues, including lignocellulose in cell walls, facilitating the evolution of uniquely specialized plant-feeding habits, such as leaf mining and stem and wood boring.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that, contrary to popular belief, larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, we find that the size of the population may actually have a negative effect on CCE. Our results suggest that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our findings have implications for the evolution of technology and the spread of ideas in general.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is the sixth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also suggest a hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is thought to have formed by crystallization of a molten iron core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we demonstrate that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hcp phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its anisotropy. They also provide a possible explanation for the origin of the Earth's magnetic field. This study may help us understand the origin of the Earth and the solar system. (Less)

The brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (MP), a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels, is a promising measure of the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation. We found that compared with controls, marijuana abusers had significantly attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine and reductions in the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation. The attenuated responses to MP, including reduced decreases in striatal dopamine, are consistent with decreased brain reactivity to the DA stimulation in marijuana abusers that might contribute to their negative emotionality (increased stress reactivity and irritability) and addictive behaviors. These findings have implications for understanding the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation in marijuana abusers and for the development of new treatments for marijuana addiction.

Language is the most complex and sophisticated form of communication. It is also unique in the extent to which it is thought to depend on a single cognitive skill: the ability to combine and rearrange words in novel ways. In this work, we show that artificial neural networks, when trained to do the same, also depend on this skill. We find that the most powerful artificial neural networks for predicting the next word in a sentence also predict brain responses to the sentence in human participants. These results provide computational evidence that the mechanisms in the brain for understanding language are shaped by the need to predict the next word in a sentence.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many scientific applications. However, it is still unclear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to find good solutions or its ability to find good solutions in a stable way. We study this question by introducing a new theory of stability for neural networks. We prove that there are cases where, even though there exists a stable neural network that can solve a problem, there is no algorithm that can find it. This result implies that the success of DL is due to its ability to find good solutions, not its ability to find stable solutions. Our results have implications for the design of DL algorithms and for the development of DL applications.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the failure of the medical system to cope with the pandemic, and the failure of people to follow the rules. In this context, it is important to understand the factors that led to the spread of the virus. In this paper, we discuss a classic psychological experiment that was cited as evidence for the failure of people to understand exponential growth. We show that the experiment’s design was flawed and that the conclusion is not supported by the data. We discuss the implications of this case study for the study of human behavior and the importance of critical thinking in science.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for millennia, and the causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been the subject of intense research. In contrast, the identity of the pathogen that causes the rare and rare-appearing disease known as Lucio’s phenomenon is unknown. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis, a bacterium that is the cause of the more common form of leprosy, and found that it is very similar to M. leprae, but also retains some functions required to cause disease in the nervous system. This suggests that M. lepromatosis may be neuropathogenic and may be a cause of Lucio’s phenomenon. Our results also suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions despite their ancient separation. (Less)

The dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a central topic of current research. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit, which is the appropriate limit to study the evolution of entanglement in quantum quenches. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle concepts, which allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the steady state. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain, and we find excellent agreement with numerical simulations. Our work provides a general framework to study the dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The only vaccine currently available is the one developed by Pfizer and BioNTech, which requires two doses, each administered 21 days apart. This study describes a vaccine candidate that can be produced in large quantities and is easy to administer. This vaccine is based on a modified version of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is attenuated and can be administered as a single dose. The vaccine candidate was shown to be highly protective in hamsters and is currently being tested in a clinical trial in humans.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that it was spread by rats. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in the study of animal cognition. However, it is often difficult to disentangle the effects of brain size and the number of neurons on cognitive ability. This study shows that, contrary to the common belief, reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer is controversial. Some studies suggest that TRAP1 is a tumor suppressor, whereas others suggest that it is an oncoprotein. We have found that TRAP1 is a metabolic regulator in cancer cells, and that its expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers. These findings suggest that TRAP1 may be a tumor suppressor in some settings.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of cellular processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is not fully understood. Here, we show that the mechanical torque exerted by the actin filament network on ADF is critical for ADF’s ability to sever actin filaments. We propose that this mechanism is critical for ADF’s function in cells. Our work provides a mechanism for how mechanical forces can regulate the activity of proteins involved in the regulation of actin dynamics. This work also provides a framework for understanding the role of mechanical forces in regulating the activity of other proteins.

The brain’s response to food cues is a major driver of overeating. In this study, we show that the brain’s response to food cues is affected by the type of carbohydrate ingested. Ingestion of fructose relative to glucose resulted in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that the type of carbohydrate ingested may influence the brain’s response to food cues and may contribute to the differential effects of these macronutrients on weight management. These results may help to explain the greater susceptibility of the human brain to the effects of fructose compared with glucose and may lead to the development of novel strategies for weight management. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, and that the settlement was not homogeneous across the island. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and provide a framework for the future studies of human diversity in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. Our results have implications for the design of social networks and for the design of interventions to improve mental health.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary source of information for protein synthesis in cells. The presence of chemical modifications in the sequence of mRNAs can alter their structure and function. In this study, we show that the most common modification in mRNA coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), can alter the rate of translation. We also show that Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can alter the rate of translation and the repertoire of peptides synthesized from a single mRNA. These results have implications for understanding the role of mRNA modifications in the regulation of protein synthesis. (Read more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social relationships, and use of time. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These results are consistent with the hypothesis that aquatic mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is a key factor in the development of the common cold. Here, we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at the cool temperature found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. We also show that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Our findings have implications for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability to sense and respond to environmental signals is a fundamental property of all living organisms. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion system to detect surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This is achieved by a mechanochemical model where the mechanical activity of type IV pili is used as a signal to activate a chemosensory system, which in turn regulates the activity of type IV pili. This study provides a new perspective on the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence. It also suggests that the mechanical activity of pili can be used as a signal in bacterial sensing systems. This finding may have implications for the design of new antibiotics that target bacterial motility systems.

The use of pesticides in agriculture is essential for food production, but their environmental impact is a major concern. In this study, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the occurrence of pesticides in surface water and sediments and their effects on aquatic organisms. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the virus responsible for the disease has spread to many animal species. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, which are the most abundant cervid in North America. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human-to-deer transmission is thought to be rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. (Less)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the history of large dams in the developing world, the problems that are being repeated, and the need to incorporate climate change into the decision-making process. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a growing need for a better understanding of the disease process. In this study, we identify the amyloid precursor protein (APP) neuron as a source of proinflammatory molecules, which may play a critical role in the development of AD. We show that the accumulation of soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) in neurons is sufficient to trigger a proinflammatory response, which may be a key event in the pathogenesis of AD. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies, as they suggest that targeting the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a promising approach for the treatment of AD.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is of great importance for the understanding of the role of this species in the development of human societies. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the folding pathway is not known for most proteins. The pathway is not known because it is difficult to study. The results reported here show that the folding of a large protein can be studied by a combination of methods that provide high structural resolution. The results show that the folding of maltose binding protein proceeds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways, and that the pathway is not known for most of the protein’s sequence. The results also show that the intermediates are obligatory steps on the folding pathway. The results are important for understanding the folding of other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress is a phenomenon that has been observed in many organisms, including bacteria, plants, and animals. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by ApaH, a protein that is inactivated by disulfide stress. Here, we show that, in the presence of disulfide stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to degrade RNA, becomes the predominant decapping enzyme. We demonstrate that, in the presence of stress, RppH decaps Np4-capped RNAs, but not their tri- and diphosphorylated counterparts, and that this enzyme prefers to decape the capped RNAs by attacking the δ-phosphate rather than the β-phosphate. This results in the production of a monophosphorylated RNA, which must be further deprotected by a second enzyme to generate the 5′ terminus needed to stimulate RNA degradation. Our findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during disulfide stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. In this study, we demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore immune function in a mouse model of sepsis. Our results suggest that citrulline could be a useful therapeutic approach to reduce mortality in sepsis patients.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system evolves at a critical rate, which is independent of its initial state. SOC systems are ubiquitous in nature and are of great interest to scientists. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, which requires further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties can be changed by external factors, such as strain. In this work, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, without phonon instability, by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, without phonon instability, by applying tensile strain. Our results can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for many applications. In addition, our results can be used to understand the properties of other materials, such as graphene, which are also subject to strain.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of fungicides. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity and their mode of action against plant fungal pathogens is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from Medicago truncatula, which exhibits potent fungicidal activity against plant fungal pathogens. We also demonstrate that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this peptide and its mode of action against plant fungal pathogens. It also opens up a new avenue for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungicide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the contributions of males and females to the reproductive process are intertwined. However, the extent of intersexual continuity is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the proteome of sperm is enriched with female-derived proteins, suggesting that the female reproductive tract may serve as a reservoir of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Read more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood clotting system. It is also a major component of the vascular system, where it is important for hemostasis. The common disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), is caused by mutations in VWF. We show that the A1 domain of VWF can be switched between two states by force, and that this switching is important for VWF function. The force-induced switching provides a mechanism for the observed gain-of-function of mutations in VWD. The force-induced switching is also consistent with the observed gain-of-function of mutations in VWF in other diseases. The results suggest that the A1 domain of VWF is a mechanosensitive protein. This is the first demonstration of a mechanosensitive protein in the vascular system. The results also suggest that the A1 domain of VWF is a mechanosensitive protein in other tissues.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered efforts to understand the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, and we use it to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results of this study will help to guide future research in this field.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the interaction process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), which can provide simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds. This instrument is capable of providing high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We use this instrument to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that the increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, which is consistent with expectations. However, the increased aerosol loading had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the origin and evolution of life. The temperature of the Earth’s surface is also important for understanding the origin and evolution of the biosphere. The temperature of the Earth’s surface is also important for understanding the origin and evolution of life. This paper presents a method for determining the temperature of the Earth’s surface in the past. The method is based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. The results of this study suggest that the temperature of the Earth’s surface decreased over geological time. This finding is consistent with previous temperature estimates based on isotopic evidence.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and the cardiovascular system. The K+ channel BK channel is a major regulator of the resting membrane potential of the heart and is also involved in the regulation of blood pressure. The BK channel is unique in that it lacks a classic activation gate and shows no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study may provide a new perspective for the study of K+ channel regulation. (Read more)

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 500,000 deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion, a process that has been the subject of intense investigation for over a century. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would suggest that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties can be changed by external factors, such as strain. In this work, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, without phonon instability, by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, without phonon instability, by applying tensile strain. Our results can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for many applications. In addition, our results can be used to understand the properties of other materials, such as graphene, which are also subject to strain.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have important implications for understanding the impact of climate change on the spread of influenza virus and the development of effective therapeutic strategies. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words merge into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation is likely to be important for tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin. We believe that this is a common feature in many redundant gene pairs in vertebrates, and that it may be important for the development of the species.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the search for its causes has led to the identification of a number of factors. One of these is the activity of the brain, which is involved in the regulation of eating. Here we describe a brain circuit that may contribute to overeating. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated animals, and that this effect is blocked by lesions of the dopamine system. We also show that this circuit is involved in the regulation of eating in the periphery, in the caudate nucleus, a region that is part of the circuit we have described.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, but its availability is limited in many agricultural systems. The use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture is a promising strategy to increase crop yields and reduce the need for chemical fertilizers. However, the efficiency of the nitrogen fixation process is low, and the bacteria are often unable to fix nitrogen in the presence of the plant. Here, we demonstrate a system that allows the control of the nitrogen fixation process in the plant, and we show that it can be used to increase the efficiency of the nitrogen fixation process. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work may also have applications in the development of synthetic microbial consortia for the remediation of nitrogen-polluted environments.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest and a critical carbon store. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, deforestation in the Amazon is still occurring at a rapid pace. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated the transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. This approach could be applied in other tropical forests.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense of many animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We show that the health benefits of reducing fossil-fuel-related emissions are comparable to those of reducing other anthropogenic sources. We also show that aerosols mask the warming caused by fossil-fuel-related emissions, and that reducing them can be beneficial for rainfall patterns. Our results indicate that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to have a devastating impact on the global population. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the disease. In this study, we report the design of a SARS-CoV-2 receptor-binding domain (RBD) variant that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. We also report the design of a virus-like particle (VLP) that can be used to present the engineered RBD. These findings provide a potential solution to the global challenge of COVID-19. The engineered RBD variant and VLP can be used to develop vaccines that can be manufactured at large scale, potentially providing a solution to the global challenge of COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALKAL family of proteins is a recently discovered group of secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric cancer. In this study, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is activated by the three zebrafish ALKALs. We also show that the three zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, a type of neural crest-derived cells. Finally, we show that the three ALKALs are able to activate human ALK and that loss of function of zebrafish ALKALs results in the loss of iridophores. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development and in the activation of ALK family receptors. This knowledge will be useful for the development of therapeutic strategies for neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a topic of great interest. The study of ancient plague genomes can provide insights into the origins of this pathogen and its adaptation to its new host. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age. Our results show that the Yersinia pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic in the Eurasian Steppe was already present in Europe, and that the plague pandemic spread across Eurasia in a stepwise manner, with a rapid increase in its geographic spread. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its adaptation to its new host. (Less)

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in predicting support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. (PsycINFO Database Record

The fate of carbon (C) in agricultural systems is a key driver of climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to crop production has released massive amounts of C to the atmosphere. However, the extent to which soil health management practices can mitigate this C loss is unknown. We show that soil health management practices can increase the amount of C stored in the soil, but the extent to which this occurs depends on the type of crop production system. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester C and provide a framework for the design of climate-smart agricultural systems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses into humans and the need for rapid, effective interventions. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to inform the development of effective strategies to prevent and control future outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the color of the red nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insights into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction. (Less)

The genetic history of Europe during the period of the Migration Period (5th–8th centuries AD) is poorly understood. Here we present genome-wide data from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and control of emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We demonstrate that mNGS can identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak in Cambodia. We also show that mNGS can be used to identify risk factors associated with undifferentiated febrile illness. These findings have implications for the rapid identification of emerging pathogens in resource-scarce settings, and the development of mNGS-based surveillance systems. This will enable the early detection of emerging pathogens and the deployment of rapid public health response. (Less)

The human genome is replicated in a complex process that involves the assembly of proteins that facilitate the synthesis of DNA. One of the most important proteins involved in this process is proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA), which is responsible for the formation of a complex that allows DNA synthesis to occur. In this study, we have used kinetic analysis to determine the stability of the PCNA-pol δ complex, which is the protein complex responsible for the synthesis of the lagging strand of DNA. Our results indicate that the stability of this complex is much lower than previously thought.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to have catalytic activity, but it has not been possible to evolve an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA. In this paper, we describe the evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA by RNA-catalyzed PCR. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.
In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which was effective in reducing mortality in severe and critical COVID-19 patients, could improve the clinical outcome immediately.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to regulate copper content and to use copper-binding natural products to mediate interactions with competing microbes is a relatively unexplored area of research. Here we report the existence of a copper-binding isocyanide natural product in fungi, and demonstrate that this product has a role in copper homeostasis and in the regulation of interactions with competing microbes.

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica that is not stable at present-day conditions on Earth. The tridymitic mudstone has ∼40 wt.% crystalline and ∼60 wt.% X-ray amorphous material and a bulk composition with ∼74 wt.% SiO2. Plagioclase (∼17 wt.% of bulk sample), tridymite (∼14 wt.%), sanidine (∼3 wt.%), cation-deficient magnetite (∼3 wt.%), cristobalite (∼2 wt.%), and anhydrite (∼1 wt.%) are the mudstone crystalline minerals. Amorphous material is silica-rich (∼39 wt.% opal-A and/or high-SiO2 glass and opal-CT), volatile-bearing (16 wt.% mixed cation sulfates, phosphates, and chlorides−perchlorates−chlorates), and has minor TiO2 and Fe2O3T oxides (∼5 wt.%).
