Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on plants and animals are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in response to climate warming, and that species in regions that are currently frost-free are likely to be exposed to increasing frost risk in the future. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is not known whether Th17 cells are required for the development of disease or whether they are simply a component of the inflammatory response. We found that Th17 cells were required for the development of disease and that they were able to support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important mediators of disease pathogenesis and may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different causes, and the mechanisms underlying the disease are not fully understood. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study the disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. This method will enable the study of the disease in a large number of patients, and will accelerate the development of ALS therapeutics.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. In this study, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp) in the vector tick, Ixodes scapularis. IAFGP is a secreted protein that binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall polymer of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings reveal a mechanism by which a human pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from its vector to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a framework for understanding the role of the gut microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents by arthropod vectors. (Read more)

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short-tailed bird group is a major group in the evolution of the avian tail, and the early members of this group are critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, which adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds.

The climate system is very complex, and it is difficult to understand the full range of its behavior. One way to make progress is to focus on the simplest possible system and understand that. Here, we show that the water cycle plays an important role in the climate system. We show that increases in water vapor in the stratosphere increase the amount of water vapor in the stratosphere, and that this leads to further increases in water vapor in the stratosphere. This process is a positive feedback, and it is the dominant positive feedback in our model.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, ranging from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can affect its ability to hide from predators, attract mates, or be camouflaged in its environment. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) can be modified by the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a compound that is the main pigment in the blood of these animals. Our results provide evidence of the evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is common in vertebrates, and describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates. Additionally, we found a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. These findings have implications for the evolution of color and for the understanding of the function of serpin family proteins. (Read more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells can be classified into two distinct populations: noncancerous cells and cancer cells. Cancer cells are characterized by the ability to form tumors and spread to other parts of the body. Cancer stem cells (CSCs) are a small subpopulation of cancer cells that are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of tumors. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor and is a marker of CSCs. Our findings have important implications for the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Read more)

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This study reports the results of a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. (Less)

The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is a matter of intense debate, and the timing of the event is critical to understanding the processes that led to it. Here we report the age of the Permian-Triassic boundary and demonstrate that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. This age is consistent with the onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle and provides a precise time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The age of the boundary also allows a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. (Less)

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the gut lumen. It is also the first line of defense against invading pathogens and environmental insults. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3)-mediated repression of NF-κB target genes is critical for the control of inflammatory responses. Our findings provide insights into the role of RORα in intestinal inflammation and suggest that therapeutic strategies targeting RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling could be beneficial for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0-Å resolution. The structure of the complex provides insight into the mechanism of receptor binding and receptor cleavage, and it will be useful for the design of vaccine candidates and therapeutics.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 82.08 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the need for urgent action to mitigate the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. (PsycINFO Database Record

The chemical behavior of matter under pressure is a topic of great interest, both from a fundamental and an applied point of view. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. Our results are of general interest, and we believe that they will be of interest to a wide audience.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, but the implications for the carbon cycle are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, as caused by socioeconomic development, can reduce fire activity, which in turn can reduce warming. This is because fires release carbon from ecosystems, and reducing fires reduces the amount of carbon released. Our results suggest that climate–carbon cycle feedbacks are most effective under lower emission scenarios, and that ignitions and fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to consider fire in climate mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is provided by the host only at dusk, when the squid is preparing to produce light. We also show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts, and that it is catabolized by the symbionts themselves, which is necessary for the acidification of the host tissue, which in turn enhances the activity of the symbionts. Our results suggest that the provision of nutrients to symbionts may be a more general mechanism for the maintenance of the health of animal tissues. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The study of topics in text data is a fundamental problem in natural language processing. We introduce a method that integrates advances in theoretical machine learning with word embedding to identify topics in text and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful in many applications.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is often explained as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which the disease established itself in European rodents. However, we show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the bacterium originated, were favorable for its spread to Europe, and that the disease was reintroduced into European harbors on multiple occasions. Our results suggest that the climate in Asia was a key factor in the establishment of the second plague pandemic in Europe.

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases to affect the California sea stars. The disease is caused by a densovirus that has spread rapidly throughout the population. We show that the virus is present in the tissues of the affected sea stars and that the disease is associated with increased viral load. We also show that the virus can be transmitted to healthy sea stars, suggesting that the disease is being spread by the virus. Finally, we show that the virus has been present in the Northeast Pacific for at least 72 y, suggesting that it may have been present during the mass mortality events of the 19th century. These findings provide a strong basis for the development of control strategies for the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. In this study, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, and that the settlement was not homogeneous across the island. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and provide a framework for the future studies of human diversity in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases dehydrogenase activity and represses genes involved in glycerol metabolism. The protein interacts with the membrane-associated glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and the glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase of galactose metabolism. The RNA also encodes a protein that interferes with the RNA’s own repression. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is the first example of a dual-function RNA in which the protein and RNA functions compete. This work provides insight into the evolution of dual-function RNAs and the mechanisms by which they compete. It also provides a mechanism for the regulation of glycerol metabolism in bacteria. This work may also be relevant to the regulation of other metabolic pathways. (Read more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and thus difficult to use in quantitative analyses. We show how to transform the original crop expert data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We also show that the crop expert data are stable over time, and can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert data can be used to provide a more accurate and timely assessment of crop status and yield prospects, which is critical for early warning systems and disaster relief.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by a number of different brain regions. In this work, we propose a model of language processing that is based on a single brain region, the inferior frontal gyrus. Our model is based on the idea that language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. We show that this can be achieved through a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our results provide a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The response of soil respiration to warming is a key indicator of the impact of climate change on the carbon cycle. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. (Less)

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a powerful tool for the study of the origin and evolution of life. In this study, we show that the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle, which is a key event in the origin of life, is linked to a relaxation of purifying selection in all plastid genes. We demonstrate that the loss of photosynthesis is not the only driver of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes, but that the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle is also a major driver of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes. Our findings have implications for the origin of life and for the study of the molecular evolution of plastid genomes in the context of the origin of life.

The impact of anthropogenic climate change on the probability of occurrence of multiyear droughts in southwestern South Africa is quantified using a high-resolution large ensemble. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of the South African water system and the need for adaptation strategies. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which these materials form are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this material, which was formed in the seconds after the explosion of the first nuclear bomb, provides a unique window into the conditions under which quasicrystals form.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and it is powered by light, which is captured by the (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments. The formation of the fifth isocyclic ring in these pigments is a key step in the light-driven conversion of solar energy to chemical energy. The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophylls is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth, and the discovery of three classes of the (bacterio)chlorophyll cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs is a major advance in our understanding of this pathway.

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we identified a key role of apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) in microglia/macrophages in the development of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a model of MS. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These results may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for EAE and other neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s recorded history. We show that the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions has increased in California over the past century, and that this increase is very likely due to human activities. Our results suggest that anthropogenic warming has increased the probability of co-occurring warm and dry conditions in California, and that the probability of such conditions will continue to increase in the future. This finding has important implications for water resources management, ecosystem health, and wildfire risk in California and elsewhere.

Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This finding provides a starting point for understanding the etiology of autism. It also provides a platform for the development of behavioral-based approaches for the discovery of autism-risk genes and the identification of causal paths. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that, on average, people react more strongly to negative than positive news content, and that this negativity bias is present in 17 countries around the world. However, individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content is also evident, and this work suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+) release-activated Ca2+ (CRAC) channel is a key regulator of cellular functions, including gene expression, cell growth and differentiation, and Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the ORAI1 channel, which result in hematological abnormalities and a congenital myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease and several forms of dementia. In this study, we use a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread in a non–cell-autonomous manner, and that this spreading is associated with the internalization and accumulation of aggregates within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the cell membrane, demonstrating that the release of aggregates is a dynamic process that requires active mechanisms. These results provide a model for the study of spreading and disease progression in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses is increasingly recognized, but the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats are not fully understood. Here, we report the isolation of a novel immunosuppressant protein (MTX) from the bat, Myotis pilosus, which is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland. MTX is a potent inhibitor of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H), which is responsible for the hydrolysis of leukotriene A4 to leukotriene B4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibits the activity of LTA4H and therefore maintains high stability of LTB4, which is a potent inducer of inflammation. We show that MTX facilitates viral infection by inhibiting the antiviral immune response of the host. This study provides deeper insight into the immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is essential for cell growth. We report the discovery of a series of small-molecule inhibitors of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, one-carbon metabolism may be a promising target for the treatment of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of ALS. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the evolution of plants, including the origin of the flowering plants. The Cretaceous is also a key time in the evolution of the aquatic plants, which are important in the history of life on land. The Cretaceous is also a key time in the evolution of the flowering plants, which are important in the history of life on land. This paper presents a detailed study of Montsechia vidalii, a Cretaceous aquatic angiosperm, and discusses its position in the evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in the field of virology, but it is difficult to study because of the lack of ancient viral sequences. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Less)

Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change. In this study, we provide a 25-y time series of global mean sea level, which is the most comprehensive time series available. We find that the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, which is significantly higher than the acceleration of the last century (0.12 ± 0.05 mm/y2). This implies that global mean sea level could rise 65 ± 12 cm by 2100 compared with 2005, roughly in agreement with the IPCC AR5 model projections. Our results also show that the contribution of thermal expansion to global mean sea level rise is 80% of the total.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been greater for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a more general erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The structure of the enzyme active site is a key determinant of the reaction pathway and the outcome of the catalytic reaction. The structure of the transition state is a key determinant of the outcome of the catalytic reaction. The structure of the transition state is a key determinant of the structure of the active site. The structure of the active site is a key determinant of the structure of the transition state. The structure of the transition state is a key determinant of the structure of the active site. The structure of the active site is a key determinant of the structure of the enzyme. The structure of the enzyme is a key determinant of the outcome of the catalytic reaction.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral that is already in clinical use, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing pandemic. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This may be of particular importance in the context of the ongoing pandemic. (PsycINFO Database Record

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a widespread strategy used by animals to regulate the composition of their microbial communities. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. We demonstrate that chitin is provided to the squid only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most metabolically active, and that this glycan is required for the acidification of the organ that enhances the activity of the symbiont. Our results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a widespread mechanism used by animals to regulate the activities of their microbial communities. This may be particularly important in the case of luminescent symbionts, which are often subject to predation and competition.

The suspension of students from school is a common and controversial practice. This study shows that it can be reduced by encouraging teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This intervention is scalable and can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is one of the most common DNA lesions, which can lead to a variety of diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions induce distinct pol II stalling profiles. Intriguingly, pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will help to understand the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis and

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These findings suggest that the first cleavages of S proteins are important determinants of MERS-CoV tropism, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. In the UK, the food system is responsible for 18% of greenhouse gas emissions, and this proportion is likely to increase as the population grows and diets become more meat-based. In this paper, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria by 50% led to a proportional increase in vegetarian meal sales of 61.8%. This is a large effect, and it is likely that similar increases in the proportion of vegetarian meals available in other settings would have a similarly large impact on greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. Our results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could be a simple and effective way of helping to reduce the environmental impact of the food system.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex system, and the surfaceome is a target for cancer therapy. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Less)

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has a large number of mutations, but the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion and/or immune suppression. These results provide insights into the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease. (Read more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a major factor in the pathogenesis of many diseases. In this study, we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic induction of the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF)/CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) pathway. We also show that the CRF/CRFR1 pathway is involved in the up-regulation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) expression in hypoxic rats and in the up-regulation of AQP4 expression in hypoxic rats in vitro. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this condition. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been “cherry picked” for the strongest associations. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding the strengths of the associations that we find in our data.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vitro and in vivo. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of vascular networks in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a new approach for the generation of vascular networks and may be useful for the regeneration of organs. Furthermore, the use of ETV2 may be a promising strategy for the treatment of ischemic disorders. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for ischemic disorders. (Read more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as physiological ligands of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research in the field of RTK biology. In this study, we explore the physiological function of these ligands in vivo and demonstrate that they play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation in the eye and the body. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for future studies on the role of augmentor ligands in human diseases. (Read more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and insulin secretion. We also found that STING deficiency in peripheral tissues and β-cells led to insulin resistance and glucose intolerance, respectively. These findings provide a possible molecular mechanism for the role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and glucose homeostasis.

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza and are responsible for occasional pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction we identified is a molecular mechanism that might be used by influenza A viruses to package their genome. The lack of conservation of this interaction among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This interaction might also be used by other RNA viruses. (Read more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and smoking. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including the local hemodynamic environment. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by the disturbed flow is a critical factor in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the progression of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the disturbed flow in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of athero-protective strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States. This has led to a substantial increase in the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. In this paper, we show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires are now dominant in the United States. We argue that this has important implications for policy and management, and that actions to reduce fire risk should focus on regions where human-caused wildfires are most prevalent.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel as a receptor of plant-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help the understanding of arthropod–plant adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe neurological complications and birth defects. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the recent surge in cases has led to a global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the rapid production of viral particles and the short eclipse phase of ZIKV in the infected cells can explain the rapid spread of the virus in the population. We also show that the antiviral treatment can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. However, the timing of the treatment is critical, and the treatment should be started as soon as possible after infection. The timing of the treatment is also critical for the antiviral favipiravir, which is currently being tested in humans. Our results can help to guide the design of clinical trials for the treatment of ZIKV. (Less)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals shed their symbiotic zooxanthellae and turn white in response to environmental stress. However, the mechanisms underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the onset of bleaching. Our results suggest that the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis is a metabolically regulated process, which is dependent on the availability of energy and nutrients. This provides a missing link in our understanding of the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis and may ultimately help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier that protects the body from the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the immune response, and the development of tumors. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors lead to a dysbiosis of the microbiome, which in turn triggers a regenerative response that stimulates tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of intestinal tumors. They may also provide a new perspective for the development of new strategies for the treatment of intestinal tumors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The development of breast cancer is a complex process that involves the interaction of multiple factors. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which also enhanced the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The timing of the onset of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is a key piece of the climate puzzle, but the cause of this event is still debated. Here we show that the onset of deglaciation is linked to a series of volcanic eruptions from Mount Takahe, Antarctica, which occurred exactly at the time of the onset of deglaciation. The eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which likely caused changes in the Southern Hemisphere climate that led to accelerated deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential ecosystem service, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Less)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens up a new platform for the discovery of novel factors that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that in other organisms. We find that the distribution of recombination in plants is similar to that in animals, suggesting that the mechanisms of recombination in plants and animals are similar.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the functional organization of the brain. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We observed that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is found on all mRNAs that are translated, and it is essential for translation. The 5′ cap structure is also found on a subset of mRNAs that are not translated. We show that a second 5′ modification, nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+), is also found on a subset of mRNAs. We also show that NAD+ is found on pre-mRNAs and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results define a second 5′ modification of mRNA in eukaryotes and raise the possibility that this 5′ NAD+ cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. This could have important implications for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. The mechanisms of metabolic memory are not fully understood. Here we show that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells from people with diabetes persist for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), the landmark study that established the benefits of intensive therapy. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. They also suggest that epigenetic modifications may be a target for therapeutic interventions to prevent or reverse the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. We also show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Read more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder that is difficult to treat. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of gut barrier dysfunction and in the behavioral symptoms of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. These findings may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for other psychiatric disorders.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is poorly understood, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also describe a pathway for the biosynthesis of these compounds, which is distinct from the known pathways for the biosynthesis of other tomato volatiles. This work provides a foundation for the development of improved tomato cultivars with enhanced flavor. (Read more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of climate change. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature, and that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight that the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning will be exacerbated by the loss of biodiversity, and that the additional impacts of warming will be greatest when species diversity is low. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning, and for our ability to design effective conservation and restoration strategies.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the mammalian brain, involved in spatial navigation and memory. It is also the target of lesions in patients with epilepsy. However, the organization of its neurons is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are important for navigation, are organized in a distinct manner from other neurons. Our results provide a detailed view of the organization of neurons in MEC and may help to elucidate the mechanisms of spatial navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Dodder is a root- and leafless parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. This study shows that the flowering of the host is required for the flowering of the dodder. This is an important finding, as it illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The cause of this disorder is unknown, but it is thought to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In this study, we describe a previously unknown type of neuron in the substantia nigra, which is a key region of the brain in Parkinson’s disease. We show that these neurons, which are densely packed into clusters, are connected to the striatum, the region of the brain that is most often affected by Parkinson’s disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection. We also seek speed. In this work, we show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We also show that this signal is used by others to gauge the quality of our social interactions. Our findings suggest that we are constantly seeking connection, and that we are always seeking speed.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, called sinoatrial cells (SACSs), which are responsible for the generation of the heart rate. The SAN is a highly regulated system, and the mechanisms that control its function are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the function of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cells of the SAN, called sinoatrial cells (SANCs), and that its deletion in SANCs results in a reduction in the content of the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores and a loss of automaticity of the SAN. These results reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the regulation of Ca2+ stores and the electrical activity of the SAN. (Read more)

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been explored. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the role of silicon in plant defense. (Less)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages, which are the main immune cells in the body.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by a number of different brain regions. In this work, we propose a model of language processing that is based on a single brain region, the inferior frontal gyrus. Our model is based on the idea that language processing involves the ability to integrate information over short periods of time. We show that this can be achieved through a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. Our results provide a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant-based therapeutics. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the siRNA-bearing DNA nanostructures determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of plant-based therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that provides many ecosystem services to society. However, it is also a highly vulnerable area that is often the first to be impacted by anthropogenic stressors. In this study, we show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. Our findings have important implications for coastal management and restoration, as well as for the design of nutrient reduction strategies for large lakes and reservoirs.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the existence of a large-scale steady state of the universe is biased toward rare combinations of initial conditions. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning of the universe may be a consequence of the dynamics of a simple chemical network.

The mechanisms by which the NMDA receptor contributes to the generation of spontaneous brain activity are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDA receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can change the dynamics of the NMDA receptor itself, as well as the dynamics of the cortical microcircuit, to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous brain activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also provide a framework for understanding the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs encephalitis. This work may also have implications for the development of new therapies for patients with NMDAR-Abs encephalitis.

The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid climate change, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global warming and that the warming was driven by an increase in atmospheric CO2. We also show that the warming was accompanied by an increase in organic matter burial and anoxia, which may have contributed to the extinction of marine life.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation, but it is an important tool in the toolbox of policies and programs that aim to reduce deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Read more)

In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with a single sex determination locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent they were born to. In species with multiple sex determination loci, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent they were born to, in addition to the sex of the parent they were born to. We show that the latter scenario can result in a much larger number of possible genotypes, and thus genotypes with different sex and sexual phenotypes. We show that this can result in modular variation in sexual phenotypes, and that the modularity of sexual phenotypes can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of the gain or loss of sex determination alleles.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by a variety of reactive oxygen species and photoproducts of reactive oxygen species. In this study, we show that the redox state of the intracellular iron pool impacts the levels of a class of reactive oxygen species scavengers, the lipofuscinic bisretinoids. We also show that the redox state of the intracellular iron pool impacts the photodegradation of a bisretinoid, A2E, which is a precursor of the damaging dicarbonyls. These findings have implications for the role of iron in the retina and for the development of strategies to protect the retina from photodamage. (Read more)

Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use their tentacles to capture prey. They are considered a model system for studying the evolution of specialization in the animal kingdom. However, the evolution of specialization in siphonophores has been considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophore specialization is not a dead end, and that it can be linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of the tentacles and their nematocysts. Our findings help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of hominin research. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and there is a gap in the fossil record of ∼800,000 y. We report the discovery of a hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene site of Kaitio, Kenya, that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand in the context of the evolution of the genus Homo. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and thus requires a constant supply of one-carbon units. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of one-carbon unit availability, and thus cell growth. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT, and show that it blocks colon cancer growth in mice. We also show that one-carbon unit demand is particularly high in B-cell cancers, and that this is due to defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of B-cell cancers that can be exploited for therapeutic benefit. This work provides a foundation for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results also highlight the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets in future research and policy.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for the expansion of arable land and the production of more food. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights, which have increased the risk of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction.
